Keywords: Avengers , Soldier
Real Name: Steve Rogers
Special Powers
AVENGERS ASSEMBLE!: Leadership. // At the beginning of the game, you may replace up to 4 other friendly standard characters with the same number of standard characters from your Sideline on their starting clicks. All replacement and replaced characters must have the Avengers keyword and different names. The total points of the replacement characters can't exceed the total points of the replaced characters.

May 22, 2022
thugit
Batman Team-Up wasn’t announced yet when I made that post. As for Legacy cards, they’re kind of fun, but only apply to random clix from days gone by, including some that very few people are still likely to have because power creep had already made them obsolete. The reason V Thor from Supernova is crazy expensive now is because there just aren’t a lot of them in existence anymore. Now that a chase figure (Rick Jones) has a legacy card, his price has skyrocketed as well—which amplifies my point about this becoming a game where only people who drop large amounts of money can remain competitive. Focusing on tournaments like ROC was a bad idea for the health of the game. Super Rares and especially chases are now absurd on the secondary market, which means a large percentage of people not only lose the ability to compete, but also miss out on some of their favorite characters.
May 9, 2022
hoojeebo
Obviously power creep exists, but I disagree with some of your other claims, and you actually kind of contradict yourself. Both Silver Age and the introduction of Legacy cards are meant to make it so that people can play older pieces again. They are literally making strides to make older sets relevant. Plus there is a known DC set in the "pipeline".
May 9, 2022
thugit
Power creep is more prevalent than ever since ROC tournaments have become intertwined with the game. Playing for money has given an excuse for WK to genuinely want older figures to be unplayable. ROC allows Silver Age and is now a huge part of the game. WK doesn’t want the biggest part of their base being able to just use what they already own. Playing some of my older DC stuff was still viable until the last two years or so. At this point, playing new stuff vs old stuff is genuinely playing a different game. There’s clearly no point formula that can explain new figures vs. older ones. Compare this guy to the 200 point Common Batman. Batman’s now at least 100 points overcosted. Add the fact that there isn’t a DC set anywhere in the known pipeline, and it’s hard for someone who wants to play DC characters to continue playing the game. The JLU set is somewhat playable, but everything beyond that truly is a different game. Huge point costs, (now) redundant powers, etc. Great for fans who want to put substantial amounts of money into the game, not so good for people who prefer to just play casually.

Who needs special powers or reducers when the base stats and dial length are so good that he'll simply outlast and beat his opponent to KO. Finally, put me in the camp that loves what Goop does for the units section. I may not always agree with his opinions, but he's definitely won a lot of figures over for me as well...just not this one.

December 29, 2021
BroVoodoo
I personally think the set as a whole isn’t necessarily underpowered. It just seems more geared towards an offensive play style than typical. Most dial designs in the set don’t offer much in the ways of defense powers/stats. I think that is purposefully done by wizkids to speed up gameplay. They are trying to find ways to bring in new players by making the game as a whole quicker and easier to understand. In my opinion this set does a really good job at that while keeping figures playable for more seasoned players.
December 29, 2021
Brundun94
This seems like the place to pontificate this thought. Overall, what our friend Goop is saying here is true... in a certain, unique context. This set is underpowered, not so much in the sense that it's unplayable, but instead that it failed to keep a tradition wizkids has had going on for about 5 years now, which is to, in the immediate sets following a DC set release, inflate the power structure. I don't say this as a DC fanboy either; go take a look for yourselves. Starting with XXS/AI after HQGG. Ever since we've had only annual DC releases, there is a subsequent jolt in dial efficiency almost immediately after every DC set. Now I'm not about to go Heroclix Illuminati here, but I would argue that this condition, intended or not, has probably started to create a sort of passive expectation in players that around every 12 or so months they can expect a big brand set with powerful, new stats (AI, SWBW, ABPI, FF, and now Empyre). Rise and Fall/Empyre just happened to break this growing trend, which honestly is great, because it's not sustainable. That being said, I think I could argue I've srudied this set pretty thoroughly, and I actually think it's a really great set. Not paradigm altering like recent counterparts, but still, there are a number of pieces in this set that will get fringe meta play, and there's a good many that are better in play than on paper, and make for great casual play, which is great for the game. Neither Empyre nor RAF will probably offer the meta as much as WW80, and that's also a good thing, because 1) Im tired of buying sets that get immediately outmoded and 2) DANGIT I WANT MY DC STUFF TO MEAN SOMETHING! :D In seriousness, overall, this is still a really good set. It just didn't blow things up as we've come to expect. For that, I can't blame Goop going through the comment sections in this set and berating it. There are a good many complaints I'd like to take to wizkids, too. Keep em honest, Goop, and all of y'all. /end tangent
December 28, 2021
BLsquared
In my opinion, this Cap has a few things going for him. The trait, if course, will be used for meta shenanigans until Kingdom Come. But his other features consist of his long dial for the cost, and his varying powers. These in combination can provide some situations where an opponent actually puts themselves in a worse position, such as hitting Cap with a close attack when he's on ESD, only to knock him onto his close combat clix. At his lower points he's definitely better for his team swapping trait, but at this value he gets a lot more done. I was one of those initially disappointed in this dial, but looking him over some more, I want to try him on a few teams and see how it plays out. In an age without perplexing damage, his supportive powers will also be invaluable. Plus he's got a form of move and attack on every click! He looks like a joy to play for fun, just so he can "keep doing this all day".

December 7, 2021
Goop
Everyone is loving that this Cap is 11 clicks long but i'm just not sold on him. Yeah its a long dial but his powers are just all over the place. These chaos type dials are incredibly difficult to play right. You are going to find yourself based with ESD or at range with CR. I would have liked him a lot more if he was just one way or another. A lot more useful at the lowest line for figure swapping.
